item.title: Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2008

latestAction.text: Received in the Senate. Read twice. Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 331.

item.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 224 - 194 (Roll no. 800). (text: CR H9579)
Passed/agreed to in House: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 224 - 194 (Roll no. 800).(text: CR H9579)
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 225 - 197 (Roll no. 799). (consideration: CR H9590-9591)
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 599.
Considered as privileged matter. (consideration: CR H9579-9588, H9589-9591)
Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 100.

The rule provides that the amendments printed in part A of the Rules Committee report shall be considered as adopted in the House and in the Committee of the Whole. No further amendment shall be in order except those printed in part B of the Rules Committee report.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 110-290, by Mr. McGovern.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 110-290, by Mr. McGovern.

summary.text: Sets forth the rule for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3161) making FY2008 appropriations for agriculture, rural development, the Food and Drug Administration, and related agencies programs.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
